urn:contentItem:7TYV-F0C1-2RYX-1068-00000-00Rann slams arson, promises support - VICTORIA ABLAZE2009-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 7Rann slams arson, promises support - VICTORIA ABLAZEJamie Walker

SOUTH AUSTRALIA

SOUTH Australian Premier Mike Rann has likened arsonists to terrorists, as he pledged to rush fire crews to bushfire-stricken Victoria.

South Australia had a temporary reprieve at the weekend when its 13-day heatwave was ended by the cool change that fanned the disastrous bushfires in Victoria.

Reflecting community anger at revelations that some of the Victorian blazes may have been deliberately lit, Mr Rann said up to 20 per cent of bushfires were caused by arsonists.

``These people are terrorists within our nation, they are the enemy within, and we have to be increasingly vigilant about them,'' he said.

South Australian emergency services remain on high alert, but milder temperatures this week will allow them to send help to Victoria.

South Australian Country Fire Service chief Euan Ferguson said 70 CFS firefighters would be deployed to Victoria by tomorrow, as well as incident management teams and water-bombing aircraft.

Flames threatened homes at Gawler, north of Adelaide, before a grassfire was brought under control on Saturday.

``Whenever the chips have been down in South Australia, Victoria has been there for us -- and we will be there for Victoria,'' Mr Rann said yesterday.

``We have conveyed to the Premier of Victoria the sorrow and the sympathy of the people of South Australia to the people of Victoria over this terrible, terrible tragedy.''

The Country Fire Service had warned ahead of Saturday's cool change that the Forest Fire Danger Index for sections of the Adelaide Hills was 111, double that for the Ash Wednesday disaster in February 1983.

Those fires killed 28 people in South Australia and 47 in Victoria. Nine people died in the Eyre Peninsula outbreak in South Australia in 2005.

Temperatures are set to return to the high 30s in South Australia by the end of the week.

urn:contentItem:7V1N-PRV1-2RYX-11BX-00000-00NEWS IN BRIEF2009-02-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 15NEWS IN BRIEF

Nuclear subs collide

A BRITISH and a French submarine, both nuclear-powered and carrying nuclear weapons, collided in the Atlantic Ocean earlier this month, The Sun reported yesterday. The British tabloid said HMS Vanguard and France's Le Triomphant were both damaged in the incident, but there were no reports of damage to the nuclear parts.

New cancer weapon

FRENCH specialists have unveiled a new weapon against cancer -- a molecular ``decoy'' that mimics DNA damage and prompts cancerous cells to kill themselves. The research opened new avenues for attacking tumours that are resistant to conventional therapy, the Curie Institute in Paris said.

Lincoln tops poll

JUST days after the US honoured the 200th anniversary of his birth, Abraham Lincoln has been ranked as the best president by 65 historians. George W. Bush was 36th out of the 42 presidents in a survey by cable channel C-SPAN. After Lincoln, the best leaders were George Washington, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Theodore Roosevelt and Harry Truman.

Gaza rockets hit Israel

PALESTINIAN rockets exploded in Israel and Israeli jets bombed the Egypt-Gaza border yesterday, as talks dragged on over a long-term truce. Hamas is demanding that Israel open Gaza's border crossings, but Israel says it will open the crossings only after Hamas releases Gilad Schalit, a soldier held by the group since June, 2006.

Valentine's sex arrests

AUTHORITIES in Malaysia arrested 26 unmarried Muslim couples in hotel rooms in the eastern beachside town of Kuantan during Operation Valentine -- aimed at curbing illegal premarital sex -- an officer said yesterday.

Fire chopper crashes

A HELICOPTER carrying firefighters from a forest fire has crashed in southern Chile, killing all 13 people on board. The helicopter hit a hillside near Chanco, about 270km south of Santiago.

Boy, 6, shoots mother

A BOY aged six has accidentally shot his mother dead with his father's gun at their home in Papua New Guinea's capital Port Moresby.

urn:contentItem:5RBH-S9W1-JD34-V4J0-00000-00Fire conditions leave central Victoria at severe risk this weekend2018-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisFire conditions leave central Victoria at severe risk this weekendChris Pedler

Authorities have again warned that the central Victorian region is under threat from potential fire this weekend.

Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said the highest risk area for fire would be the area from Melbourne to Echuca.

"Through the outer metropolitan areas, central Victoria, northern Victoria and all of western Victoria is the highest area of risk," he said.

"The most elevated risk - due to the temperatures, the types of fuel conditions and the weather - is in western and central Victoria.

"One of the key issues on Saturday is that it will be a hot, dry and windy day."

The warning comes 12 months after emergency authorities singled out the strip of land between Melbourne and Echuca as being most at risk from devastating bushfires.

Commissioner Lapsley said in the past seven days, emergency crews have experienced 25 grass and bush fires per day.

"That's with mild conditions, no strong winds, just nice days. What that confirms to us is the fuels are dry," he said.

"The grass and and forests are dry enough to carry fires.

"You add a hot day tomorrow, a dry and windy day means the potential for erratic fire behaviour and intense fires in those locations."

Victorians are urged to make calculated and responsible decisions.

"Responsible decision making is key," Commissioner Lapsley said. "It's about being measured and calculated in the decision you make for your safety and other people's safety."

Commissioner Lapsley said the anticipated wind change was a key element for the day.

The wind change is expected in central Victoria between 4pm and 5pm on Saturday.

"It's a key safety issue for firefighters but for a community it changes the direction of a fire," he said.

"If we have a fire in the afternoon being fuelled by a north-westerly wind, which is where the wind will start, and that wind turns to the west or south west it changes the progression of a fire.

"(That wind) will move across the state and we expect it to be in central Victoria and out metropolitan areas in the afternoon.

"That means we will have a wind change in the highest populated area, at the hottest part of the day, which means it will be a very risky period."

Commissioner Lapsley said fire crews were in a good position with no significant fires running.

"We will have fires (Friday) afternoon but believe the conditions this afternoon will allow us to get in control of those as they start," he said.

"That means we will hopefully start tomorrow with no fires of any significance running anywhere in the state. That's a good place to be.

"From then you have full capability of Forest Fire Victoria, CFA and Metropolitan Fire Brigades as well as full fleet of 49 aircraft - an increase of aircraft we had last year."

EMERGENCY services across the region are prepared for the extreme weather condition forecast this weekend.

Three Incident Control Centres have been set up in the Loddon Mallee region - one in Bendigo, one in Mildura and on in Gisborne.

A Regional Control Centre has also been setup in Queen Street.

Loddon Mallee regional controller Mark Cattell said emergency services began planning for the control centres late last week.

"We had an indication that there was going to be a spike day in the weather on Saturday," he said.

"From there we began discussing (plans) and by Monday had determined that it would mean extreme fire danger in the Mallee and Wimmera regions and severe conditions in most other regions.

"There's been a lot of discussion in how bad things could get and from there have set up Incident Control Centres in those three areas.

"We have a standard operating procedure that determines if the fire danger is at a certain level, we need that readiness."

Mr Cattell said more than 40 incident control centres were set up across the state.

"We will be in place from 10am and given the information we have, we are looking at being set up for about 14 hours," he said.

The Bureau of Meteorology says parts of Victoria will face severe and extreme fire danger periods over the weekend.

A heatwave is expected to arrive on Saturday with temperatures in the low to mid 40s set for most of Victoria. Bendigo is forecast to reach 42 degrees.

Acting manager of the BOM extreme weather desk James Taylor said fire dangers were a particular concern this weekend.

"Severe to extreme fire dangers are set for western Victoria," he said. "Any fires that start in that area will be difficult to suppress. People need to be aware of their local conditions."

Mr Taylor said the heatwave will move across Victoria on Saturday before a cool change arrives in the evening.

He advised people to stay up to date with weather conditions and warnings via www.bom.gov.au

VicRoads is urging drivers to take care while driving in extreme heat.

Drivers are advised to keep up to date with traffic and weather conditions as well as not taking unnecessary trips in adverse conditions.

If you must travel on days of extreme weather, inform someone of which route you plan to take and how long you think it will take to arrive at your destination and carry plenty of fresh drinking water.

Never leave children or pets unattended in a car as temperatures rise to dangerous levels quickly.

While travelling, children and pets require additional precautions to protect them. Consider using rear window shades and remember that the back seat and cargo areas can be considerably warmer than the front-seat area.

Vehicle breakdowns are more likely to occur in extreme heat.

High fire dangers have also prompted Crime Stoppers to warn people considering breaking the total fire ban.

Crime Stoppers is urging Victorians to look out for anyone disobeying total fire ban restrictions, including lighting fires in the open air or carrying out hot work such as welding or grinding.

"People that choose to ignore total fire bans are putting our communities at risk. We urge anyone with information about illegal or reckless fire activity to please report it to Crime Stoppers," Crime Stoppers Victoria general manager Cathy Rhodes said.

Penalties for causing a bushfire include up to 15 years in prison or fines of over $36,000. The maximum penalty for arson resulting in death is 25 years in prison.

urn:contentItem:52H8-FM11-F0JP-W26W-00000-00Homeowners will pay Sell-off to push up timber prices, association says2011-03-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Homeowners will pay Sell-off to push up timber prices, association saysRURAL EDITOR NIGEL AUSTIN

ADELAIDE homeowners will pay up to 30 per cent more to build new homes if South-East forests are sold overseas, it has been warned.

The price rise will be passed on to homeowners as timber merchants are forced to import timber at significantly higher prices than they pay for local timber.

The Hardware Association of SA made the claim in Mount Gambier yesterday at the Australian Senate Inquiry into the sale of Timber Assets by the South Australian Government. Association chairman Rod Evins said if the Forestry SA timber was sold, local businesses would have to pay up to twice as much for timber from overseas.

Mr Evins, also chairman of the Banner Hardware Group, said he was concerned about the implications for South Australia because Forestry SA provided 75 per cent of the timber used in SA and 85 per cent of Banner's timber.

``We can't provide enough timber as it is, we have to import now,'' he said.

The planned sale was already having dire consequences on the South-East, with Banner's timber plant in the South-East recording a 60 per cent drop in sales in January. Mount Gambier Mayor Steve Perryman, District Council of Grant Mayor Richard Sage and Wattle Range Council Mayor Peter Gandolfi said the sale put the jobs of 600 timber industry workers, 3000 contractors and many more at risk.

Housing Industry Associaton regional director Robert Harding said: ``If we lose the local supply chain and we have to source the timber from overseas, then we are at risk on a whole range of things. The quality, the quantity that may be reduced; price will then become difficult to manage because it will depend very much on transport availability and transport costs and the strength of the Australian dollar, all of which we would not have control over,'' he said.

Committee member Senator Nick Xenophon said it was clear the SA Government had not thought the whole process through.

``The evidence is incredibly alarming, it's like a slow-motion train wreck,'' Mr Xenophon said.

``The idea is flawed, the process is a sham and the outcome would be a disaster.''

urn:contentItem:5RBH-NW91-F0J6-J45N-00000-00Fire conditions leave central Victoria at severe risk this weekend2018-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEFire conditions leave central Victoria at severe risk this weekendChris Pedler

Authorities have again warned that the central Victorian region is under threat from potential fire this weekend.

Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley said the highest risk area for fire would be the area from Melbourne to Echuca.

"Through the outer metropolitan areas, central Victoria, northern Victoria and all of western Victoria is the highest area of risk," he said.

"The most elevated risk - due to the temperatures, the types of fuel conditions and the weather - is in western and central Victoria.

"One of the key issues on Saturday is that it will be a hot, dry and windy day."

The warning comes 12 months after emergency authorities singled out the strip of land between Melbourne and Echuca as being most at risk from devastating bushfires.

Commissioner Lapsley said in the past seven days, emergency crews have experienced 25 grass and bush fires per day.

"That's with mild conditions, no strong winds, just nice days. What that confirms to us is the fuels are dry," he said.

"The grass and and forests are dry enough to carry fires.

"You add a hot day tomorrow, a dry and windy day means the potential for erratic fire behaviour and intense fires in those locations."

Victorians are urged to make calculated and responsible decisions.

"Responsible decision making is key," Commissioner Lapsley said. "It's about being measured and calculated in the decision you make for your safety and other people's safety."

Commissioner Lapsley said the anticipated wind change was a key element for the day.

The wind change is expected in central Victoria between 4pm and 5pm on Saturday.

"It's a key safety issue for firefighters but for a community it changes the direction of a fire," he said.

"If we have a fire in the afternoon being fuelled by a north-westerly wind, which is where the wind will start, and that wind turns to the west or south west it changes the progression of a fire.

"(That wind) will move across the state and we expect it to be in central Victoria and out metropolitan areas in the afternoon.

"That means we will have a wind change in the highest populated area, at the hottest part of the day, which means it will be a very risky period."

Commissioner Lapsley said fire crews were in a good position with no significant fires running.

"We will have fires (Friday) afternoon but believe the conditions this afternoon will allow us to get in control of those as they start," he said.

"That means we will hopefully start tomorrow with no fires of any significance running anywhere in the state. That's a good place to be.

"From then you have full capability of Forest Fire Victoria, CFA and Metropolitan Fire Brigades as well as full fleet of 49 aircraft - an increase of aircraft we had last year."

EMERGENCY services across the region are prepared for the extreme weather condition forecast this weekend.

Three Incident Control Centres have been set up in the Loddon Mallee region - one in Bendigo, one in Mildura and on in Gisborne.

A Regional Control Centre has also been setup in Queen Street.

Loddon Mallee regional controller Mark Cattell said emergency services began planning for the control centres late last week.

"We had an indication that there was going to be a spike day in the weather on Saturday," he said.

"From there we began discussing (plans) and by Monday had determined that it would mean extreme fire danger in the Mallee and Wimmera regions and severe conditions in most other regions.

"There's been a lot of discussion in how bad things could get and from there have set up Incident Control Centres in those three areas.

"We have a standard operating procedure that determines if the fire danger is at a certain level, we need that readiness."

Mr Cattell said more than 40 incident control centres were set up across the state.

"We will be in place from 10am and given the information we have, we are looking at being set up for about 14 hours," he said.

The Bureau of Meteorology says parts of Victoria will face severe and extreme fire danger periods over the weekend.

A heatwave is expected to arrive on Saturday with temperatures in the low to mid 40s set for most of Victoria. Bendigo is forecast to reach 42 degrees.

Acting manager of the BOM extreme weather desk James Taylor said fire dangers were a particular concern this weekend.

"Severe to extreme fire dangers are set for western Victoria," he said. "Any fires that start in that area will be difficult to suppress. People need to be aware of their local conditions."

Mr Taylor said the heatwave will move across Victoria on Saturday before a cool change arrives in the evening.

He advised people to stay up to date with weather conditions and warnings via www.bom.gov.au

VicRoads is urging drivers to take care while driving in extreme heat.

Drivers are advised to keep up to date with traffic and weather conditions as well as not taking unnecessary trips in adverse conditions.

If you must travel on days of extreme weather, inform someone of which route you plan to take and how long you think it will take to arrive at your destination and carry plenty of fresh drinking water.

Never leave children or pets unattended in a car as temperatures rise to dangerous levels quickly.

While travelling, children and pets require additional precautions to protect them. Consider using rear window shades and remember that the back seat and cargo areas can be considerably warmer than the front-seat area.

Vehicle breakdowns are more likely to occur in extreme heat.

High fire dangers have also prompted Crime Stoppers to warn people considering breaking the total fire ban.

Crime Stoppers is urging Victorians to look out for anyone disobeying total fire ban restrictions, including lighting fires in the open air or carrying out hot work such as welding or grinding.

"People that choose to ignore total fire bans are putting our communities at risk. We urge anyone with information about illegal or reckless fire activity to please report it to Crime Stoppers," Crime Stoppers Victoria general manager Cathy Rhodes said.

Penalties for causing a bushfire include up to 15 years in prison or fines of over $36,000. The maximum penalty for arson resulting in death is 25 years in prison.

urn:contentItem:5SGM-G2W1-F0NT-H359-00000-00Making the elephant dance: DELWP secretary John Bradley2018-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisMaking the elephant dance: DELWP secretary John BradleyABSTRACT

Victoria's top environment bureaucrat John Bradley discusses his varied career, making systems work and collaborating with the community.

FULL TEXT

John Bradley is not sure if he always wanted to be a public servant, but looking back now, there were certainly hints.

"I came across a piece of artwork I'd done when I was in grade one, which was a picture of my father talking to the government on the phone," laughs the secretary of Victoria's Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning.

"Clearly there was some kind of odd obsession at that point with government."

Bradley's public sector career started out while studying public administration at the University of Queensland.

"Literally my first job was working in the mailroom, as per the cliche," he told The Mandarin.

As a graduate he started out in emergency services, before moving to rail reform. The 1990s was "a significant period of change in that industry", he explains. "That got me very interested in microeconomic reform generally and put me into the Treasury portfolio, and into energy and utilities work after that."

Much of his career since then has been in those areas, though his stint as CEO at the Queensland Water Commission during the millennium drought stands out.

"Part of that was being put into a genuine crisis environment where a community of 2.8 million people was facing a water security crisis that could have seen dam levels fall below levels able to maintain sufficient supply," he says.

Big changes had to happen to ensure the sustainability of Queensland's water supply. The industry was restructured, new regulatory frameworks established, water saving targets introduced, and water use behaviour change campaigns undertaken.

"There was a complete change in the culture of the community with regard to water use and sustainability," he says.

Prior to his appointment to DELWP nine months ago, taking over from Adam Fennessy, Bradley worked as director general of Queensland's Department of Environment and Resource Management, a consulting executive to the International Monetary Fund, and CEO of energy industry peak body Energy Networks Australia.

That might sound like a disparate collection of experiences to some, but it makes sense to Bradley.

"The common theme across my work, and it's very common for a lot of other people, is systems. When I think about the frameworks around microeconomic reform, they were a big part of my early career working in rail reform and electricity and gas," Bradley explains.

"Find the career sweet spot between what you find rewarding and what best contributes to the community."

"A lot of those issues were establishing systems supporting the realisation of the public policy purpose, the outcomes the consumers were after, and it wasn't too dissimilar for me when I then went into working in water, dealing with Queensland's water security during the millennium drought, to be thinking about the systems and institutional structures that were supporting better outcomes for consumers.

"It's not a too different bridge then to think about the environmental portfolio and natural resource management as systems. So there are some common themes there, as odd as it might sound to have a background in utilities and environmental and natural resource management."

Keeping an open mind and being prepared to be mobile opens many doors, he thinks. Find the career sweet spot between what you find rewarding and what best contributes to the community.

"If you're open to applying your expertise and skills in good public policy, project management, community engagement and effective communication, those common skillsets will really allow you to go anywhere across government, but they'll also set you up to move into other sectors and jurisdictions."

He was also, in 2011 and 2012, director general of the Queensland Department of Premier and Cabinet.

"It's challenging as the CEO of a government agency when you're leading a significant department with multiple portfolio responsibilities, but it's almost a different role again when you're in those central agencies and you're working with the breadth of government on collective activities.

"I worked for a minister in the past who used to refer to 'trying to make the elephant dance' as being the objective of a minister, and I think sometimes that the director of the Department of Premier and Cabinet has to make all the elephants dance, or help the elephants to dance."
Diversity and breadth of mega-department
Since starting as secretary at the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, a mega-department employing over 3400 staff in 81 locations, one of the things that's surprised Bradley has been the "diversity and breadth of the department's touchpoint with the community".

This includes everything from protecting the mountain pygmy possum to water catchments, the development of Melbourne, safeguarding the water supply against climate change and the operation of state forests.

Victoria has just seven departments, so many of the portfolios that would have their own agency in other jurisdictions are collected in the one structure. While it might make it difficult to remember DELWP's full name, the mega-department approach allows for more effective coordination across policy responsibilities.

"It's an absolute strength of the Victorian system and an absolute strength of our department that we have responsibility for such a broad set of activities that are all interrelated," says Bradley.

It means DELWP needs to be proactive about making sure issues don't fall between the cracks of this giant bureaucracy, but the risks outweigh the benefits.

"When we think about the potential across planning systems, water catchment management and supply, across energy, environment and climate change, local government responsibilities, and then forest fire and regional service delivery, the coordination of all those activities in a really agile way gives us the ability to deliver some great outcomes for the community at place.

"When you think about the fact that the same agency has responsibility for the government's renewable energy targets and planning frameworks and climate change, this has to be a great opportunity for synergies across our agency."

DELWP is currently undergoing a big shift in its working style, giving communities a stronger say on issues that affect them. Backburning is one such area.

"We're bringing them into the planning process and making explicit to them in some way what our criteria are for how we're going to manage planned burning and protect the community from bushfire risk -- the tradeoffs and choices," Bradley explains.

"There's a dimension of ecological impact we need to manage really carefully, there's community safety, then there's issues of economic activity where you have vignerons and others who are really conscious of the impacts of planned burning and want to be carefully consulted, or tourism destinations that will have concerns if we're not carefully engaging them in the decision-making process by which we do planned burning.

"All of those things are transforming a model of fire management and planned burning which previously was just done within the agency and just delivered to the community as an outcome to the community. It's bringing the community in a participatory way into how we make those kinds of decisions."

urn:contentItem:5BYB-6VB1-JD3N-5364-00000-00SPIN DOCTOR2014-04-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 9SPIN DOCTORIAIN SHEDDEN

MISSY Higgins, John Butler and the Cat Empire are among the contributors to a new album designed to help save the Great Barrier Reef. The 21-song collection Songs for the Reef is part of the WWF Australia's campaign to fight plans for a coal port at the region's Abbot Point. Higgins, meanwhile, has been busy working on the next phase of her career. We hear there's an album on the way this year but, for the first time, the songs won't be hers. She's recording an album of Australian cover versions.

ALSO busy in the studio recently have been the reunited Sydney duo Angus & Julia Stone. The siblings went their separate ways after the international acclaim for their second album Down the Way, and its single Big Jet Plane. They recorded solo albums instead, although there was an aborted attempt to record their third album together last year. Now it has happened, thanks to the skills and determination of legendary American producer Rick Rubin, who invited them to record in his studio, with him at the helm, after seeing them perform separately. Still in the studio, country star Kasey Chambers has just been recording her new solo album in Byron Bay with Powderfinger producer Nick DiDia. We can expect all of these works-in-progress in the second half of the year.

FURTHER from home, veteran British singer-songwriter Lloyd Cole, he of Perfect Skin, Forest Fire and Rattlesnakes with his band the Commotions, releases his new solo album, Standards, on May 9. To coincide with the release, Cole, a regular visitor to Australia, will be touring here in June and July. Not only will he be performing but he'll also be conducting a couple of in-conversation sessions hosted by the Hawke Research Institute. Cole will speak at the University of South Australia and at Hobart's Museum of Old and New Art on the topic "music singles to Spotify".Unlike on previous visits, Cole won't be pursuing his passion for golf on Australia's top courses. Too busy, he says.

IT doesn't seem like any time at all since the last Record Store Day, the annual event that takes place across the world to encourage and preserve the idea of walking into a shop and buying some vinyl or other recorded product. With sales of old and new vinyl on the rise, this year's event in Australia, on April 19, is shaping up to be the biggest in its history, with hundreds of artists performing or releasing special material to mark the occasion. Among them, Melbourne's Dan Sultan, whose new album, Blackbird, has just been released, will be doing an in-store at Readings in Melbourne at 2pm on the day. In Adelaide, local favourites the Audreys, also with a new album, 'Til My tears Roll Away, in tow, will be performing songs from it at Blackwood Sounds at midday. Magic Dirt singer Adalita, meanwhile, is marking the occasion by re-releasing her debut self-titled solo album on two discs of vinyl, one of them blood red and the other gold. It will be restricted to 500 copies.spindoc@theaustralian.com.au

urn:contentItem:548M-6001-JD67-100D-00000-00Home bush clearing laws changed2011-11-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Home bush clearing laws changedCLAY LUCAS STATE POLITICAL REPORTER With BENJAMIN PREISS

HOMEOWNERS in Victoria's most bushfire-prone areas will from today be able to clear all vegetation except trees up to 50 metres from their house without a permit, under laws brought in by Planning Minister Matthew Guy. Before now, householders had been able to clear shrubs and vegetation within 30 metres of their house. Under the new "10/50" rule, to be passed in state parliament today, they can legally clear any tree or bush within 10 metres of their home, and bushes or native vegetation within 50 metres.

Mr Guy also said new homes would be better fire-proofed as a result of the new laws that give councils far stronger controls to reject houses and other proposals they believe will not meet stringent requirements. "The new planning provisions give priority to the protection of human life," Mr Guy said. The opposition said the changes, to clearing in particular, were months later than expected, and had put people living in areas of high bushfire risk in greater danger. The Greens said the new laws could result in overly aggressive clearing, and could lead to some residents clearing with false motives. The new rules, the government's response to the 2009 Victoria Bushfires Royal Commission, will result in every planning scheme in the state being changed to better consider the possibility of bushfires when a new house is being built. Housing groups last night voiced concerns that the new laws rated too much of Victoria as high risk, and would bump up building costs. Housing Industry Association spokeswoman Kristin Brookfield said "arbitrary assessment" of bushfire risks would increase costs for roofing, guttering, and seals around doors and windows. Mr Guy also announced a time extension on planning permit exemptions for people living in temporary housing in bushfire-affected communities. Extended until early 2013, they would give time to resolve long-term building plans, he said. "Travellers in country Victoria are among those most vulnerable to the growing threat of grass fires this summer. Fire Services Commissioner Craig Lapsley said a warm August followed by heavy rain had created the right conditions for grass growth and fires. "People get caught in the open or out on roads in grass fires," he said. Grass fires are thought to pose the greatest risk in central and north-western Victoria. They can travel up to three times faster than a forest fire. The Country Fire Authority says that complacency over bushfires has become worrying.

urn:contentItem:4K19-4770-TX52-H1VR-00000-00Warriors gather2006-05-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisFEATURESLeaderPg. 28

MATP

Warriors gather

THIS time of year, every year, an age-old enmity flares up like a raging forest fire and brother is set against brother, friend against friend, as the battle lines are drawn.

Today two vast armies -- variously arrayed in the blue or maroon regalia of their warrior clans, will circle the field of conflict to watch their champions fight for supremacy.

Nothing less than the states' pride is at stake, so no quarter will be given -- none asked.

It's State of Origin time again, and the warlike comparisons are apt, for both the Queenslanders -- desperate for a reversal of fortune after three straight series defeats -- and the mighty Blues of NSW, relishing their status as dominant champions, are approaching the series with military efficiency and ruthlessness.

The State of Origin, regarded in rugby league circles as the defining contest, never fails to drive passion and excitement to feverish heights -- but this year expect super-heated levels of energy.

For this will the test for the new champions as the old order shifts. Although Joey Johns might yet play, there will be no Shane Webcke, no big Ben Kennedy, no Gordon Tallis. Time then for today's stars -- Lockyer, Gasnier, Mason, O'Meley, Thurston, Bowen -- to come into their own as the new rulers of rugby league.

What a night it will be.

Pg. 8</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Indonesian games mask a deeper tragedy</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA: Athletes and officials began arriving today for the 1997 South-East Asian Games armed with devalued currencies and surgical masks to combat smog as environmental and financial crises threatened to take the shine off the event.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> More than 4600 athletes are expected for the 10-day competition from Saturday, hoping that a forest-fire haze from embarrassed hosts and defending overall champion, Indonesia, will not blow into town and spoil the party.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Games officials have guaranteed clean air, but team officials are not taking any chances.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP, Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>The Philippines' Sports Commission chief Philip Juico said his 843-member delegation, including 619 athletes, would be arriving with 1000 face masks in addition to medicine for respiratory problems and sore eyes.</p><p> Special masks, nose and eye drops are also on the 397-member Singapore team's list of medical musts, while Thailand took the extra step of putting on standby two Royal Thai Air Force C-130 aircraft for medical and environmental emergencies.</p><p> The Vietnamese women's soccer team, a possible gold medal contender, added 60 masks and 100 tube inhalers to their kit.</p><p> Widespread forest infernos sparked by slash and burn farming methods have been raging out of control across Indonesia the past four months, throwing up a mantle of smog over large parts of South-East Asia which disrupted training schedules.</p><p> The crisis has aggravated the financial turmoil that has seen regional currencies lose more than 30 per cent of their value against the US dollar and skewered delegation budgets. The hosts slashed the opening ceremony budget by 29 per cent on the orders of President Suharto after the rupiah fell to historic lows.</p><p>Jakarta has shelled out 24.23 billion rupiah ($9.7 million) for their 826 mostly foreign-trained athletes, but officials said they were still four billion rupiah short after some sponsors backed out due to currency concerns.</p><p>Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said yesterday the brush and forest fires on Sumatra and Borneo causing smog across South-East Asia had not strained ties with Jakarta's neighbours.</p><p> "There is no strain between Indonesian and neighbouring countries because there is a mutual understanding between ASEAN countries," he said. "It is a pity, what has happened here also involved our neighbouring countries. We are concerned, but don't forget that all the losses as well as health and economic problems, mostly affect our country."</p><p> His comments came as The Straits Times, perceived to reflect official thinking in Singapore, said ASEAN should set up a system to fight such regional disasters to salvage its credibility on the ground.</p><p> The fires had given the nine-member ASEAN another reason for being, it said in an editorial, noting that ASEAN environmental ministers had been involved in the forest fire problem since 1991.</p><p> "But in spite of exhaustive discussions and many promises, action on the ground remains disappointingly meagre. That must be remedied now, as much to save the region from such disasters as to salvage ASEAN's credibility at the operational level," the editorial stated.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5J5H-GRN1-F0J6-J3KC-00000-00POPE'S VIEW2016-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 26POPE'S VIEW

Matter of emergency

National health statistics see the North West Coast as one of the areas in the nation with significant sickness and chronic disease, with diabetes and heart diseases being amongst the highest in the nation.

This being the case, why is it that our government would want to deny a proportion of its people the best health facilities it can to support the community?

In the instance of a heart attack it is critical that a patient receives attention within a short period of time, 60 minutes to be exact.

If this was your loved one would you not want to be able to see them safely delivered to the nearest hospital? If you live in Devonport, Sheffield, Port Sorell and Shearwater.

In the ten years the largest growth in West and North West was in Port Sorell, which grew by 1,200 people, Sheffield - Railton (900). The fastest population growth was in Port Sorell (30%), followed by Miandetta - Don (up 18%) on Devonport's outskirts, and Latrobe (17%) (ABS, 2016).

So to protect our health and keep us alive, please hands off the Mersey Hospital. We need it!

TAMMY MILNE

Devonport

Fires get more intense

I recently had the opportunity to personally thank some interstate firefighters for helping us during an hour of need.

Having experience in emergency services at a personal level (mines rescue) which includes firefighting, and having worked within the South West wilderness area, we could all see the risk of havoc, build up of "forest fire fuel" will (not just could) present in the future.

For thousands of years under Aboriginal management, regular fuel reduction and regeneration burns took place as nature intended it.

However, since the "experts" have taken over and locked it away, fires these days don't just manage the undergrowth ... they are so fuel-laden, they burn the natural "canopies". Also, intense as they are, the build up could burn for decades not just months, as peat moss smoulders even in the wettest environments.

It's to be hoped the experts take note and we can strike middle ground harmony.

DARRELL POKE

Ambleside

Debt of gratitude

The discrediting of the massive fire fighting effort being waged, under difficult and dangerous circumstances, is simply deplorable.

How can any fair minded person attack the professionalism of our fire fighters by claiming a lack of effort to arguably save two per cent of our World Heritage Area from wildfire when you consider the remaining 98% could have easily been destroyed without their effort?

As a Tasmanian I believe we owe a debt of gratitude to all our state, interstate and NZ firefighters for being ready and willing to saving our wilderness and community areas from these devastating wildfires.

LYELL DEAN

Westbury

Question of power

Energy Minister Matthew Groom has attracted criticism in recent times regarding electricity supplies in our State.

However, in amongst the controversy, Adam Langenberg's article, "No need to use less power, Premier says" (Adv., Feb 13), gives us some further insight to the reality of the current, and possible future situation, in respect to the Basslink cable service.

Groom mentions that contingencies to address power supply requirements would include diesel generators, additional generation at the Tamar Valley Power Station, and reduction deals with industrial users.

Further, these measures would provide more energy than a fully operational Basslink.

If Groom's perspective is an accurate reflection of the situation's reality, we can rest assured that the unusual limitations of the current Hydro service can be addressed by the temporary measures mentioned above.

On a positive note, regarding the proposed use of diesel generators, crude oil on the international market is at a relatively low price - thus possibly resulting in lower diesel prices.

Something that domestic power consumers would welcome in respect to the temporary use of diesel generators.

PARIS SHACKLOCK

Devonport

Bad idea, Treasurer

Treasurer Scott Morrison is considering looking after casual and part time workers by transferring into their pay packets what is currently being set aside by their employers for superannuation.

It is obvious what the result of that will be.

The additional cash workers receive will put them over their award.

Result, staff will be replaced and replacements employed on basic award with no superannuation and "bingo" another additional benefit for the coalition mates and more Australians working poor.

Now that's looking after ya!!

WALLY REYNOLDS

Perth

urn:contentItem:4MWN-MF10-TXDB-H20H-00000-00Firefighters reveal Tumut region fire concerns2007-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisFirefighters reveal Tumut region fire concerns

Volunteer firefighters at a recent fire near Tumut have voiced concerns that they were not given adequate information about the area during firefighting efforts.

It took hundreds of firefighters a week-and-a-half to bring the 11,500 hectare plantation forest fire that burned near Tumut in December under control.

At a debrief on Monday night, volunteers said poor communication and a lack of maps was a problem.

Bill Kingwall, the captain of the Rural Fire Service (RFS) Adjungbilly Brigade, says the issue of maps was raised with authorities after major fires in the region in 2003.

"The duplication of the command structure, not having any information, the maps and the printed sheets just weren't distributed at Adjungbilly in the week that we were there - our brigade received one and it was a second hand [one] from a forestry sector commander," he said.

There is also concern about problems accessing the fire because of blackberry bushes.

Tony Klee, the Superintendent for Riverina Highlands RFS, says the issues raised by the volunteers will be taken up the chain to a management committee meeting at the end of the month.

"When you look at the magnitude of the fire and the days it ran obviously not everyone would have got the maps that would have been nice for them to have," he said.

"However, all our tankers would have had a full set of maps covering most of the areas that they would work in. However, the ACT came over one day and they had mapping from helicopters which they are able to supply back to the ground and that is technology catching up."

urn:contentItem:4MPD-GT90-TX5J-S2TG-00000-00Fires reduce gas2006-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisPg. 8Fires reduce gas

NT blazes trail to limit greenhouse emissions

By PAUL JACKSON

THE Territory has a head start on the world with the possibile use of fire to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, an international conference has been told.

The new research was revealed at the Fifth International Forest Fire Research Conference in Coimbra, Portugal.

Bushfires NT spatial scientist Andrew Edwards presented the results of his research on NT savanna fires to the world's leading fire researchers.

The results were from a 10-year study of the impact of various fire regimes across habitats in three big NT reserves -- Kakadu, Litchfield and Nitmiluk national parks.

''The tropical savannas of northern Australia represent a significant proportion of the world's grasslands and are also the most frequently affected by fire,'' Mr Edwards said.

''In the future world of carbon accounting, northern Australia has a head start in how it might be best to use fire for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and for the best forms of all types of land management, while maintaining the highest possible level of biodiversity.

''By mapping the effects of recent fire regimes using data from satellite imagery over the past 20 years, we are beginning to understand the effect these regimes have had on

vegetation.

''The research also highlights that fires can increase diversity.

''A high frequency of very-low-severity-intensity fires can help create a high diversity of plant species and ages.''

Mr Edwards said his attendance at the conference highlighted the importance of northern Australia in relation to bushfire issues on a global scale.

He said the conference, held every four years, was a good opportunity to network with Australian,

European and north American colleagues and help Territory scientists to insert their research into international projects.

urn:contentItem:4N03-HTT0-TX4S-M299-00000-00We must all fix the carbon mess2007-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisAPg. 17We must all fix the carbon messDANIEL COHEN

IN A RECENT effort to prove his environmental credentials, British Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged to pay 89.82 ($A228) to offset the carbon emissions produced in a recent family flight to Miami.

This is an example of the "carbon neutral" argument, currently in vogue, that one may guiltlessly produce carbon emissions for instance, by driving a car, flying in an aeroplane, or using energy inefficient appliances so long as one compensates for these emissions by planting [or paying a company to plant] enough trees to absorb an equivalent amount of carbon.

By doing this one may reduce one's net emissions to zero and so, it is claimed, one will have done nothing wrong.

This reasoning is hypocritical.

Our duties extend beyond merely mopping up our own messes.

People with surplus resources (such as Blair) have the duty not only to reduce their own emissions, but also to help mop up the emissions of others.

By analogy, consider the following case. You are camping in the bush, cooking your breakfast on a fire. The flames jump a few metres, creating the beginning of a potentially devastating bushfire. If you do nothing, you think to yourself, you will be responsible for the ensuing damage.

Luckily, you have enough water in your backpack to put out the flames, and, breathing a sigh of relief, you stop the fire before it spreads. Later in the day, on your walk back home, you come across another fire that has just started.

Perhaps it was lit by a lightning strike or by a passing pyromaniac.

You have just enough water to douse the flames, but you say to yourself "the damage resulting from this fire will be very unfortunate, but it won't be my responsibility. My net contribution to forest fire damage is zero, so I will have nothing to feel guilty about if I leave this fire to spread". Leaving the fire, you rush back to your car, take a cooling drink of water, and drive home to safety.

Clearly there is something wrong with your thinking in this story. Surely you are just as responsible for the damage caused by a fire that you could easily have put out irrespective of whether you lit it or not. You did the right thing in putting out the morning fire, but you have plenty to feel guilty about for not putting out the afternoon fire.

Return now to the case of carbon emissions. The carbon in the atmosphere, and constantly pumped out by our factories, is already a threat to everyone.

Metaphorically speaking, we are the midst of a vast forest fire. What does this entail in terms of our ethical duties?

A conservative approach is simply to say that each person should halt or mop up their own carbon emissions, so their emissions are reduced to a net zero. (This is the carbon neutral claim.)

On this approach, one has no further duty to do anything to help absorb the unchecked emissions of others. Metaphorically, one has no duty to help put out the flames started by others.

This view is subject to the same hypocrisy of the self-focused bushwalker.

To avoid this kind of hypocrisy, I suggest the following alternative view of our ethical obligations with regard to carbon emissions: We each have a duty not only to check our own carbon emissions and to help soak them up, but also to promote the checking of other people's emissions and to do what we can to soak them up too.

Planting trees is clearly a good thing.

Any policy that reduces the carbon in our atmosphere is more than mere "window-dressing", a criticism that is sometimes levelled against the carbon neutral movement.

However, because we each have a duty to reduce overall carbon emissions, it is not enough merely to reduce one's own emissions to a net zero.

Because we have a duty also to soak up the carbon negligently emitted by others, we should pay companies to plant trees, but we should also refrain from driving, from flying overseas, and from using energy inefficient appliances when possible.

People with the ability to reduce overall carbon emissions have plenty to feel guilty about if they take the self-satisfied approach of simply offsetting their own emissions.

Daniel Cohen is a research fellow with the Centre for Applied Philosophy and Public Ethics based at Charles Sturt University, the University of Melbourne, and the Australian National University.

urn:contentItem:5BBC-T9Y1-F0J6-J55K-00000-00Facing facts: they saved us all2014-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Facing facts: they saved us allJustine Doherty

IN A move which may 'spread like a forest fire' on other firegrounds, one Mountain Lagoon resident has found a way to show her profound appreciation for what Rural Fire Brigade volunteers did for her community last October.

Kooryn Sheaves came up with creating a 'road of remembrance' with firefighters' faces on Mountain Lagoon Road, which was the final line in the sand for stopping the State Mine fire roaring through Bilpin.

Ms Sheaves tells of the traumatic atmosphere when the community was told what was approaching them.

"Mountain Lagoon's population, about 42, attended a meeting at our fire shed where we were told of the dire nature of our situation as the fire front approached," she said.

"However what heartened and filled us with courage at that terrible time was that we were not alone in facing this pending disaster - volunteer fire crews from across Sydney and the state were on their way to help us.

"As emergency messages to evacuate were being broadcast through all media outlets and the police established road blocks around us, ordinary people stopped what they we doing, put on their yellows, got in a fire truck and headed for Mountain Lagoon.

"These individual acts of selfless generosity are being acknowledged in the 'Road of Remembrance' as photos of the faces of those who came are being displayed on poles along the fire line on Mountain Lagoon Road."

She was particularly blown away by the age of the volunteers from the northern beaches brigades, which she said were a contrast to the reactions of some of the adult children of Mountain Lagoon residents who claimed they were "too scared to come back and help". "We're all so old here at Mountain Lagoon - there are only two or three of us under 50," she said. "But the northern beaches brigades were all young people who were all so excited to be involved."

While Ms Sheaves has already made up helmeted faces of the local brigade members for the project, she is calling for those who came from Sydney's northern suburbs to submit a face photo of themselves and their brigade colleagues so everyone who fought was celebrated.

Ms Sheaves is placing the faces, complete with helmets and backflaps, on sticks in the bush along Mountain Lagoon Road, "until the fire season is over and evidence of our trauma eventually passes", she said. "The help you gave is remembered."

Mountain Lagoon's captain Tim Bourke was very touched by Ms Sheaves' gesture.

"It's great that local people recognise the efforts of the firefighters and show it in such an original and unusual way," he said. "It's much appreciated."

Ms Sheaves has also put up a YouTube video on the firefighters' efforts. Go to YouTube Forest of Fire Fighters to see where and how the face photos will be displayed. Email face photos of anyone involved not from the local brigade to Kooryn.Sheaves@gmail.com or go to Facebook - Mountain Lagoon Fires if you would like more details on the project.

Kooryn Sheaves' 'forest of firefighters' celebrates those who fought at Mountain Lagoon.

urn:contentItem:5K91-Y531-F0J6-J3W1-00000-00A little help from friends2016-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMCulturePg. 13A little help from friendsMUSICTIM BYRON

On his way to Melbourne, James Blake explains why he's learnt to let go. BY TIM BYRON

London-born singer-songwriter-producer James Blake has a voice you suspect would sound sad singing about sunshine, rainbows and lollipops, and his music has the kind of languid electronics that feel positively icy. His most recent album, The Colour in Anything, had critics using phrases such as "impressionistic melancholy" to describe the album's emotional palette.

Perhaps surprisingly, Blake comes across as positively upbeat. "I'm in a good place," he says. "It feels a lot easier to wake up every day and look forward to what it brings."

Of course, it doesn't hurt that a lot of big names want to work with him right now. Recently, Blake found himself in Kanye West's studio, as the rapper talked to Madonna on the phone. At some point in the conversation, Madonna asked to talk to him. "It's one of those moments where someone's pointing over to you and you're like, 'me?' and looking around to see if they mean someone else."

So what do you say when Madonna phones Kanye and then wants to say hello to you? The answer, according to Blake, was perhaps inevitable: "Yeah, hi! Oh, thank you. Uh, OK, bye!"

"It was very sweet," he says. However, Blake demurs when it is suggested that it must be odd to hang out with extroverts such as Kanye and Madonna, as a person who is a bit introverted and self-conscious. "To be honest, I'm not really [introverted]. I'm a very social person, and I'm not afraid of anybody."

Blake, 27, was born into a musical family; his father played guitar in 1970s prog rock bands. Upon finishing school, Blake completed a degree in popular music from Goldsmiths University of London; he even submitted his 2010 Klavierwerke EP as a uni assessment.

Blake first toured Australia in 2011 after releasing his self-titled debut album; triple J presenter Linda Marigliano says "his [2011] single The Wilhelm Scream was the first track [of his that] we played, and the one that really introduced him to his audience".

Blake's distinctive sound has had a profound influence on mainstream pop music. Recent No.1 singles such as Zayn's Pillowtalk or Gnash's I Hate You, I Love You would sound quite different without Blake's musical impact.

But when I ask Blake what his distinctive sound means to him, he's dismissive. "I think it now means absolutely nothing. As it crops up in other places, it loses its currency. Now, I don't have any intention of adhering to that sound."

Blake's newly found inner peace, seemingly, is not the result of success, it's something simpler: letting go.

Until The Colour in Anything, his guiding ethos was do-it-yourself. Between the melodies, the lyrics, the beats, the glitchy electronic sounds, the vocals and the gospel piano, previous records have been all James Blake - he even engineered and mixed them. But the pressure was starting to get to him.

"I just felt like I was living in a pressure cooker, and my head space was getting worse and worse," he says. "I felt like I wasn't progressing at the rate I wanted to, and I was kind of dwelling in a rut."

He decided to go for a different approach on The Colour in Anything: collaboration. Part of the album was recorded with superstar producer Rick Rubin in "one of the most beautiful places on Earth, Malibu, on the sea front, just exploring music. It really was one of the most defining moments in my life.

"It really does absolve you of a lot of pressure when you start to let other people help you," he says.

And when the guy with the hip, influential sound decides he's open to collaboration, it's no surprise that big names line up to collaborate with him, from Kanye to R&B singers such as Beyonce and Frank Ocean. Justin Vernon of Bon Iver, who appears on I Need a Forest Fire, tweeted that the song came from "wonderful accidents and good friendship".

Blake also appears on Beyonce's Forward (which he also co-wrote), from her recent album Lemonade. "I didn't consider it something I would have a lot of control over," says Blake of his initial worries about the collaboration. "But in the end, what I did was used with such respect that it gave me a reason to want to go and do it again."

His openness to experience extends to his live shows. "We know that the support in Australia is fantastic. I think we're going to have a really good time."

James Blake plays the Margaret Court Arena on July 27.

PHOTO: James Blake looks forward to "a really good time" in Australia. PHOTO: GETTY IMAGES

urn:contentItem:4SV6-CSY0-TXN5-S12H-00000-00Climate change threatens weather havoc for Western Port2008-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Climate change threatens weather havoc for Western PortMathew Murphy, energy reporter

VICTORIA'S Western Port region is at risk of experiencing more bushfires, rising sea levels, higher temperatures and the once-in-a-century storm becoming an annual occurrence unless measures are taken to combat climate change.

The grim warning forms part of a comprehensive two-year study by the CSIRO and economists Marsden Jacob Associates set to be released today.

The report, obtained by The Age, found that a rise in sea levels would "undoubtedly" affect Western Port's low-lying coastline, with the townships on Phillip Island, Tooradin, Warneet and Hastings most at risk.

The impact on the local economy, tourist attractions including surrounding beaches, property and human health could be substantial, it warns.

Fears have also been expressed for the local penguin population, one of Victoria's most popular tourist attractions, with a separate report being undertaken to determine the risks of climate change to the penguin colony.

In the worst-case scenario, the study predicts temperature increases of 1.1 degrees by 2030 and 3.5 degrees by 2070, with heat-related human deaths set to rise to 53 annually by 2100.

"The Western Port region is significantly exposed to climate extremes and natural hazards such as storm surges and coastal inundation, floods, bushfires and extreme temperatures. These hazards are expected to increase in frequency and/or severity," the report says.

"(It will have direct impact on) land use and management, damages and maintenance costs to public and private property and infrastructure, human health and water availability."

The report, which was funded by the federal and state governments and has received local government input, will be used by all levels of government to formulate climate-change policy and comes a week before the Government's climate-change adviser, Ross Garnaut, releases his draft report into emissions trading.

Dr Kathy McInnes, one of the report authors, said the low-lying Western Port region had been selected because it was particularly vulnerable. Many of the findings would be relevant to other coastal areas.

"This information will help prioritise the areas of the community that are particularly at risk and how we climate-proof the area," she said.

The report also projects that:

· By 2070, extreme rainfall will increase by up to 70%, depending on location. However, average rainfall is expected to decline by up to 8% by 2030 and up to 23% by 2070.

· Sea levels will rise by up to 0.17 metres by 2030 and up to 0.49 metres by 2070, with vulnerable areas in Western Port to increase by up to 15% by 2030 and 63% by 2070. More than 2000 individuals, more than 1000 dwellings and property worth about $780 million will be affected.

· The number of "very high" and "extreme" forest fire days in the Western Port region will increase by one or two days by 2030 and two to seven days by 2050.

The modelling did not take into account an emissions trading scheme or the Federal Government's commitment to a 60% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

Greg Hunt, executive officer of the Western Port Greenhouse Alliance, which commissioned the report, said it was not designed to be alarmist.

"I would refer to my fridge magnet and be alert but not alarmed. I don't know that people would want to get their house and jack it up on stilts just yet," he said. "What this shows is that we need leadership from all three tiers of government. We are going to need some engineering solutions, and our engineers are looking at that."

Peter Kinrade, of Marsden Jacob Associates, said governments had the power to ensure the forecasts did not eventuate.

"A lot of those impacts outlined are potentially manageable as long as there is a proactive and strategic response to the issue," he said.

SEA-LEVEL RISE

Presumed sea-level rise: 0.17 metres by 2030 and up to 0.49 metres by 2070.

One-in-100-year storm could become an annual event by 2070. The land in the Western Port area suseptible to storms will increase by up to 15% by 2030 and 63% by 2070.

More than 2000 individuals, over 1000 dwellings and approximately $780 million in property value at risk.

TEMPERATURES

Temperatures in the region will increase by up to 1.1 degrees by 2030 and up to 3.5 degrees by 2070.

RAINFALL

By 2070 extreme rainfall is projected to increase by up to 70% depending on location.

Average rainfall to decline by 8% by 2030 and 23% by 2070.

BUSHFIRES

Increased threat of bushfires. Number of "very high" and "extreme" forest fire risk days in the Western Port region will increasde by 1 or 2 days by 2030 and 2 to 7 days by 2050.

LINK

· To read the full report go to www.wpga.org.au

urn:contentItem:7WBS-T6N0-YBDY-R0J1-00000-00Firewatch bid ignored2009-08-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Firewatch bid ignoredTechnology| Bryan Allchin

A HI-tech bushfire detection system that can work 24 hours a day, tell the difference between a forest fire, dust, cloud or mist, and which has proven successful overseas is being ignored by Victorian authorities.

Firewatch Australia's chief executive David Goodrich said he had sent information about his company's system to Victoria's Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin on July 9. ``When I didn't hear back from him after two weeks, I have made calls to his office but have still had no response,'' Mr Goodrich said.

He said the German-developed Firewatch was not new, and the German network of 156 sensors had proven the system's viability.

``It was installed in Germany nine years ago, and since then, the amount of the forest burnt has decreased by more than 90 per cent.'' ``This is the findings from the German fire authorities.''

Unlike fire towers that only operate in daylight, the sensors collect data from a 400-700 square kilometre area, depending on the topography, 24 hours a day, with information being fed through smoke-detecting software.

``The system can identify more than 16,000 shades of grey and is able to determine the difference between smoke from a bushfire to smoke from a barbecue, fog or cloud,'' Mr Goodrich said. The system has found support from McEwen federal Liberal MP Fran Bailey, who has been in Europe inspecting the technology and said she would be asking Prime Minister Kevin Rudd to authorise a trial when Parliament resumes tomorrow, Tuesday.

Mr Goodrich said if his company received the go-ahead he was confident a trial system could be up and running by summer. ``It would cost between $40 million and $60 million for a national roll-out on the entire east coast and the west, if the government wanted a full roll-out,'' he said.

The Office of the Emergency Services Commissioner did not respond to Leader's inquiries.

Should we trial such a fire-spotting system? Have your say at lilydaleleader.com.au

urn:contentItem:805R-Y6G0-YBDY-R2M6-00000-00IN BRIEF2010-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 26IN BRIEF

Breast growth in babies

CHINA will test a wider range of dairy products and even breast milk as authorities investigate claims that a brand of infant formula caused apparent breast growth in a small number of babies.

State media have said the babies with apparent breast growth were found to have abnormal levels of the hormones estradiol and prolactin, which stimulate lactation, or the making of breast milk.

Testing that includes samples of breast milk would help investigators pinpoint the source of the hormones, said Peter Ben Embarek, a food safety expert for the World Health Organisation. AP

Fire risk to nuke centre denied

A FOREST fire raging close to Russia's top nuclear research centre does not risk causing a nuclear disaster, and the situation is no longer critical, the national atomic agency chief says.

The Sarov nuclear centre, 500km east of Moscow, has been menaced for two weeks by fires raging in a neighbouring nature park, Rosatom nuclear agency boss Sergei Kiriyenko said on Saturday.

``We can say today for sure that there is no nuclear risk, no radioactive threat and that there is not even an ecological threat on Sarov territory,'' he said.- AFP

Japanese leaders avoid shrine

JAPAN yesterday commemorated the 65th anniversary of its surrender in World War II without the ministerial visits to a controversial war shrine.

For the first time in 25 years, no government minister has been to Tokyo's Yasukuni shrine, a place dedicated to 2.5 million war dead, including 14 war criminals.

The anniversary is the first since Prime Minister Naoto Kan's centre-left Democratic Party ousted the conservative Liberal Democratic Party last year after its almost unbroken half century in power.- AFP

$1b taken from jailed mafia mate

ITALIAN police have confiscated $1 billion in cash and property belonging to a mafia-linked businessman in Sicily, the Carabinieri paramilitary police said.

The money and property were frozen after the arrest of Michele Aiello, 56, who has since been jailed for 15 1/2 years for mafia activities, fraud and corruption.- AFP

Siberian tiger kills keeper

A SIBERIAN tiger mauled a keeper to death in eastern China after being left to roam the cage as it was being cleaned, state media says.

Zhan Guanshun was fatally bitten on the neck while cleaning the cage at a wildlife rescue centre in Anhui province on Saturday.- AFP
